newsitem.title: SWEDEN: FORECAST-Analysts see no move in Sweden repo Tues.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST-Analysts see no move in Sweden repo Tues.

text.p: Sweden's central bank, the Riksbank, will not lower its key interest rate, the repo rate, from its current level of 4.10 percent at its weekly operation on Tuesday, a Reuters poll of 10 economists found on Monday.
However the economists were not saying the bank's lowering of the repo rate was over.
"The rumours about the spring budget proposal (to be released on Tuesday) are not worrying and the crown is heading in the right direction," said Marco Pianelli, Nomura Bank economist.
"The figures tomorrow will show that there is room for more cuts. In a month or so I think that the rate will be lowered."
Finance Minister Erik Asbrink will present the Social Democratic government's spring budget proposal at 1100 GMT on Tuesday.

In addition, Statistics Sweden will release March CPI figures at 0715 GMT on Tuesday with analysts in a Reuter poll expecting a 0.4 percent rise in March from February, for a year-on-year fall of 0.4 percent.

However some economists said that if the crown did not start to show a stronger trend in coming months then the time to lower the repo would start to run out. Last year the Riksbank cut the repo 25 times, from a starting level of 8.91 percent. The repo is the bank's key tool for controlling money market liquidity.
While the repo currently stands at 4.10 percent, the bank's other key rates, the deposit and lending rates, stand at 3.75 percent and 5.25 percent respectively.
Economists interviewed for the poll were from Carnegie, Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, Handelsbanken, HSBC Midland Bank, Merrill Lynch, PaineWebber, Paribas, S-E-Banken, Swedbank, and Unibank Markets.
